data.title: All the Way Boys (1972)
data.meta_description: The "Trinity" crew makes another modern era film. Plata and Salud are pilots ditching aircraft for insurance money. They wind up crashing for real in the jungles of South America. The plot involves "Mr. Big", who is buying the diamonds from the miners for much too little, and has thugs who keep the price down. Of course, Plata and Salud side with the miners
data.text:
1972 In Review - December

#12

A bush-flying duo crash-land in the heart of the Peruvian jungle where an unscrupulous speculator controls a precious emerald source and an entire mining community. Can they right the wrongs, and in the process, manage to make a profit?

A very disappointing outing for my favourite 70’s Italian buddies. Every Terence Hill/Bud Spencer movie should contain vast quantities of slapstick, bean eating and lots of crazy fist fighting. There isn’t enough of any of those. We get only a few fights but that’s not enough.

Two reckless pilots (Bud Spencer & Terence Hill) crash planes in the South American jungle in order to collect the insurance but get into trouble when they mess with Mr. Ears who runs his own shady business there...

SpencerHill have accompanied me through my cinematic journey starting in my childhood and they've been beloved faves ever since. Sure, the 'art of dubbing' in the shape of wordsmith Rainer Brandt added a lot to the fun factor as he through in a ton of über-hilarious sweary dialogue but it's ultimately the screen presence and chemistry of these two guys who punch first and ask questions later. Still, they keep their movies 'clean' and ultimately resort to their big hearts (that night flight…
